runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this story is about a family that visits a farm with dairy cows. Explain that dairy cows make the milk we drink and pour on our cereal. Ask students what else they like to eat with milk.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
are good things that come out of doing or having something.
of exercising are having good health and more energy.
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names how Mr. Cooper feels about the cow spa. (proud)
Why does Mr. Cooper call the barn a cow spa? Find the sentences that answer the question.
What benefits does Happy Cow Farm give its cows? How do these benefits affect the milk the cows make?
What is a food or drink that makes you happy? What does it taste like?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Explain that Locusts is a photo comic. It has panels and text boxes like a comic, but it features photos and facts instead of illustrations and dialogue for a story. Explain that this text gives information about  a kind of grasshopper called a locust. Ask students to point to the locust on page 8.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is a time when people or animals come together as a group.
: A wedding is one example of a
: When do people in your family come together for a
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the words that tell what colors locusts can be. (brown or yellow)
of locusts be mistaken for? Find the sentence that answers the question.
How can you tell that a
of locusts is quite large? Why can a swarm of locusts be dangerous as well?
What other insects do you know about? Do people try to get rid of them? Why or why not?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisper-read each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with diphthong
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.

Discuss the related words that form phrases in sentences 6, 8, and 10. Model how to chunk the text into meaningful phrases as you read each sentence. Have students echoread the sentences, replicating your phrasing.
Read the title. Explain that these are riddles. Each riddle gives clues to help readers guess a word.

For the first reading, have students read the riddle and you read the answer. Then pair students to reread the riddles. Partners can switch roles during the rereadingone reads the riddle and the other answers it.
Prompt students to find all the words with
spellings in the riddles and answers and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read about how electricity provides power for lights and other electrical devices.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is the thing or place from which something comes.
: A sink and a drinking fountain are each a
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names where to find power wires we cannot see. (underground)
of electricity in most towns? What is the
of electricity inside a home or office? Find sentences that answer these questions.
The author states that electricity makes our lives easier in many ways. Do you agree? Why or why not?
How might your life be different if you didnt have electricity at school? At home?
Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with diphthong
spellings. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 1 (question mark), 3 (period), and 9 (exclamation point).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with excitement). Have students echo read the sentences, replicating your intonation.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text explains how a battery provides power in the form of electricity. It includes a diagram. Authors include diagrams to help readers understand how something works.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the diagram.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the diagram.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read an informational text about how people keep food cold.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means useful and easy to use.
way to carry your books between home and school.
: Think of something you use that is
. What makes it useful or easy to use?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that names the area where people could not store food in frozen lakes. (South)
How did people keep food cold before refrigerators were invented? Find the sentences that answer the question.
household item? How would life today be different without refrigerators? Why?
What other appliances and devices do you and your family use that are
? How do they make life easier?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this is a fictional, or made-up, story about a family with a new baby. Ask students how someones life at home might change when a new baby arrives.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.

? How did this make you feel?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that means the same as yell. (shout)
What did Maria notice about her mothers singing? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How can you tell that Maria is a
big sister? Why does Marias mother say she is proud of her?
Maria shows talent with her laptop and music. What is a talent you have? How do you use it?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
